Subgroup

Let $G$ be a monoid. A subset $H \subset G$ is called a submonoid if $H$ satisfies the following conditions: (i) $e \in H$, (ii) $a, b \in H \Longrightarrow a b \in H$. If $G$ is a group, $H$ is called a subgroup of $G$ if in addition, (iii) $a \in H \Longrightarrow a^{-1} \in H$. In particular, a subgroup of a group $G$ is a submonoid that is closed under the process of taking inverses. In defining a subgroup $H \subset G$, condition (i) can be weakened by simply requiring $H \neq \emptyset$, since this implies $e \in H$ using (ii) and (iii). Of course, similar reasoning is not possible for monoids. Every group $G$ admits $\{e\}$ and $G$ as trivial subgroups. Given $m \in \mathbb{Z}$, the set $m \mathbb{Z}$ consisting of all integral multiples of $m$ is a subgroup of the additive group $\mathbb{Z}$. We will see in 1.3/4 that all subgroups of $\mathbb{Z}$ are of this type. More generally, every element $a$ of a group $G$ gives rise to a so-called cyclic subgroup of $G$. It consists of all powers $a^{n}, n \in \mathbb{Z}$, where we put $a^{n}=\left(a^{-1}\right)^{-n}$ for $n<0; see also Section 1.3.
Right Coset
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A right coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $Ha = \{ha; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
Polynomial Ring

Given a commutative ring R, the polynomial ring R[X] is the set of all sequences (a_i) where a_i in R and a_i=0 for almost all i, equipped with addition and multiplication defined by (a_i)+(b_i)=(a_i+b_i) and (a_i) 
cdot (b_i)=(c_i) where c_i=
sum_{
u+
u=i} a_
u b_
u. Elements of R[X] can be written as 
sum_{i=0}^n a_i X^i where X is the sequence (0,1,0,0,...).
Ring Monomorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a monomorphism if it is injective.
Least common multiple

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.
System of generators
A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called a system of generators of M if M = sum_{i in I} A x_i.
Free A-module

An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.
Algebraic Field Extension
The extension field $L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if every element $\alpha \in L$ is algebraic over $K$.
Splitting Field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield

A field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is a splitting field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ if the polynomial factorizes into linear factors in $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$. This implies that $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ contains all zeros of $X^q-X$.
Galois extension
An extension $K_{r} / K$ is Galois if it is both normal and separable.
Disjoint Cycles
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A right coset is defined in terms of a subgroup of a group. Therefore, the concept of a subgroup must be defined before defining a right coset.

A ring monomorphism is a specific type of ring homomorphism, which implies that the concept of a ring homomorphism must be defined first. However, the concept of a ring homomorphism is not explicitly listed here, so we assume the general concept of a ring is needed.
A free A-module is defined in terms of a system of generators. Therefore, the concept of a system of generators must be defined before defining a free A-module.

An algebraic field extension is defined in terms of an extension field and the base field. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined first. However, the concept of a field is not explicitly listed here, so we assume the general concept of a field is needed.
A splitting field of a polynomial is defined in terms of the polynomial and its factorization. Therefore, the concept of a polynomial ring must be defined before defining a splitting field.

A Galois extension is defined in terms of being normal and separable, which are properties related to field extensions. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined before defining a Galois extension.
